jeopardy_round: THE NEW YORK TIMES NEWS OF 2006

(1, 1).clue: There was gold in the hills of this host city as the Times noted the start of the Winter Olympics there on Feb. 10

(2, 1).clue: Not only "Jeopardy!" but this game show based on a letters-&-words board game debuted in 1984

(4, 1).clue: Eruptions in 512 were so violent that Theodoric the Goth of Italy suspended taxes for those living on its slopes

(5, 1).clue: Don't worry--Cricket Cola isn't flavored with crickets but with this "colorful" tea

(6, 1).clue: The Bethesda Fountain overlooks the lake in this New York City park

(1, 2).clue: On Feb. 13, the Times reported Dick Cheney shot a man hunting, the first shooting by a sitting veep since this man

(2, 2).clue: The Huxtables began their 8-year dominance of the Nielsen ratings on this sitcom

(3, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew opens a large reference book.)  This feature you'll find in some dictionaries helps you get quickly to the letter you want

(4, 2).clue: Lassen Peak in the southernmost part of this range was believed extinct until it erupted on May 30, 1914

(5, 2).clue: In November 2003 the Jones Soda Company introduced an unusual soda flavored with this bird & gravy

(6, 2).clue: It's said that Goethe's granddaughter posed for the statue that tops this capital city's Austria Fountain

(1, 3).clue: "G.O.P. UNREST OVER PORTS" read a headline when this emirate's control of some U.S. ports was opposed by Congress in March

(2, 3).clue: Penelope was the real first name of this title Soleil Moon Frye character who had her own show in 1984

(3, 3).clue: This forward section of a rocket or guided missile contains the payload

(4, 3).clue: This volcano on the southeast slope of Mauna Loa has had a hotel on its rim since 1866

(5, 3).clue: This "paternal" brand of root beer has been a family favorite since 1937

(6, 3).clue: King Matyas Corvinus & his beloved Ilonka adorn the Matyas Fountain at this Hungarian city's Royal Palace

(1, 4).clue: Riots in this Ugandan capital city were reported in the Times on Feb. 26 following presidential elections there

(2, 4).clue: Fred Dryer was on the beat in 1984 tracking down bad guys as this title LAPD homicide detective

(3, 4).clue: Raymond Moley was part of the group of smarties called this who advised FDR

(4, 4).clue: Figurative name of the volcanic belt that nearly encircles the Pacific Ocean

(5, 4).clue: A famous 1967 ad campaign told folks that this was actually "the Uncola"

(6, 4).clue: Unveiled in 2004, the Hyde Park Fountain that memorializes her is a deceptively simple-looking oval granite ring

(1, 5).clue: "A DRAMA STRAIGHT FROM THE TABLOIDS" blared the Times in a story on her appearance before the U.S. Supreme Court in March

(2, 5).clue: A probationary angel & an ex-cop helped people solve problems on this Michael Landon starrer

(3, 5).clue: It's what the "AR" stands for in "START I", a strategic treaty signed by Bush & Gorbachev

(4, 5).clue: This Philippine volcano's 1991 eruption was one of the largest of the 20th century

(5, 5).clue: With "twice the caffeine", it calls itself "The Espresso of Colas"

(6, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reads from Tivoli in Copenhagen, Denmark.)  The famous bubble fountain here at Tivoli was co-designed by this Danish physicist who won a 1922 Nobel Prize

(1, 1).clue: This capital, population 280,000, is one half of the "Twin Cities"

(2, 1).clue: She is the British baroness seen here as she looked in the 1980s

(3, 1).clue: This wartime thriller about a German sub inspired a classic 1981 foreign movie

(4, 1).clue: In the 1600s mustard makers in this French city organized a guild to control the quality of their product

(6, 1).clue: This & behold: it means "see" & is frequently used in Biblical expressions

(1, 2).clue: The Golden North Salmon Derby is one of the annual events celebrated in this state capital

(2, 2).clue: She's the widow at Windsor seen here in 1897

(3, 2).clue: A young lawyer defends a black Vietnam hero who murdered white rapists in this first John Grisham legal thriller

(4, 2).clue: This spice is also known as black sugar & sweetroot

(6, 2).clue: You can call your pop this, used in Italian personal names, originally to indicate place of origin

(1, 3).clue: Montana's largest city, it was founded in 1882 & named for a president of the Northern Pacific Railway

(3, 3).clue: 2005's "Marker" is the 25th medical thriller from this bestselling physician/author

(4, 3).clue: Also known as Jamaica pepper, it sounds like a hodgepodge of other flavorings

(6, 3).clue: It's the first-person singular present indicative of be

(1, 4).clue: Named for an Army chaplain, this city near Phoenix boasts more than 300 sunny days per year

(3, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew strolls through Gorky Park, Moscow, Russia.)  A 1981 thriller by this author opens with the discovery of 3 faceless corpses here in the title setting, Moscow's Gorky Park

(4, 4).clue: This red-hot, pungent powder made from various tropical chiles originated in French Guiana

(6, 4).clue: The 16th letter of the Greek alphabet, it's also a math term

(1, 5).clue: In 1802 a French chemist built gunpowder mills near this Delaware city; they became DuPont, now based there

(2, 5).clue: This general & war hero slowed down long enough to be captured (on film) around 1945

(3, 5).clue: FBI agent Alex Cross tangles with villains known as the Wolf & the Weasel in his "London Bridges"

(4, 5).clue: Plants producing this spice in England came from a crocus bulb smuggled from the Holy Land in the 14th century

(6, 5).clue: A small hawk, or a moon of Jupiter

(0, 0).clue: In 2005, as the shuttle Discovery prepared for landing, NASA played a Dexys Midnight Runners song in her honor
